case_name: Bihar State Mukhtars Association v. Chief Justice and Judges of the Patna High Court

facts.text: Petition No. 117 of 1958 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 11 7 of 1958. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental-Rights.

facts.text: Petition filed on behalf of Bihar State Mukhtars Association, Patna and its Vice-President and General Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: This is a writ petition oil behalf of the Bihar State Mukhtars Association, Patna and the Vice- President and the General Secretary thereof.

facts.text: Petition heard ex parte as no appearance on behalf of Chief Justice and Judges of Patna High Court, the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The petition has been heard exparte as there, has been numberappearance on behalf of the Chief Justice and Judges of the Patna High Court who were cited as respondents to the petition.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by K. Das, J. on August 29, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: K. Garg, M. K. Ramamurthi S. C. Agarwala and D. P. Singh, for the petitioners. The respondent did number appear. 1961 August 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAs, J.

facts.text: Patna High Court made rules in 1922 under section 11 of the Legal Practitioners Act, 1879 regarding functions, powers and duties of Mukhtars in subordinate courts.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners companytend that certain rules of the Patna High Court made as far back as 1922 under s.11 of the Legal Practitioners Act, 1879  Act XVIII of 1879 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, in respect of the functions., powers and duties of Mukhtars practising in the subordinate companyrts

facts.text: Rule 2 made by Patna High Court under s.11 of the Act, incorporated in Chapter III, Part VII of the General Rules and Circular Orders of the High Court of Judicature at Patna (Civil), 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners have, in particular, challenged the validity of r. 2 made by the said High Court under s. 11 of the Act and incorporated in Chapter III, Part VII of the General Rules and Circular Orders of the High Court of Judicature at Patna  Civil , 1922.

facts.text: Bihar State Mukhtars Association formed some 30 years back to protect interests of Mukhtars practising in courts subordinate to Patna High Court under s.3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners state that the Bihar State Mukhtars Association was formed some 30 years back with the object of generally protecting the interests of the Mukhtars in the State of Bihar practising in the companyrts subordinate to the High Court of Patna within the meaning of s. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: Association passed resolutions at various annual conferences to move High Court for removal of restriction imposed by r.2 on Mukhtars in subordinate civil courts.

anchor.surface_text: At its various annual companyferences the said Association passed resolutions to move the high Court for the removal of the restriction imposed by r. 2 aforesaid on the right of Mukhtars practising in subordinate civil companyrts.

facts.text: High Court did not remove the restriction imposed by r.2.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did number remove the restriction.

facts.text: On July 27, 1958, emergent Executive Committee meeting of Association resolved to move Supreme Court under Art.32.

anchor.surface_text: On July 27, 1958 at an emergent Executive Committee meeting of the Association it was. resolved to move the Supreme Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Present writ petition filed in pursuance of the resolution of July 27, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The present writ petition has been filed in pursuance of that resolution.

facts.text: Mukhtarship examination abolished some time in the year 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: This examination was known as the Mukhtarship examination. It was abolished some time in the year 1947-48.

facts.text: Rule 2: A Mukhtar shall not be allowed to address any Civil Court except for the purpose of stating the nature and effect of his application or to offer any legal argument or to examine any witness without the leave of the Court specially given.

anchor.surface_text: One of these rules is r. 2 which is in these terms. Rule 2 A Mukhtar shall number be allowed to address any Civil Court except for the purpose of stating the nature , and. effect of his application or to offer any legal argument or to examine any witness without the leave of the Court specially given.

facts.text: Petitioners contend that rules contravene fundamental right under Art.19(1)(g) and not saved by cl.6.

anchor.surface_text: are number invalid and void, because they companytravene the fundamental right of the petitioners guaranteed under Art. 19 1  g  of the Constitution of India and are number saved by cl.  6  thereof.

facts.text: Petitioners challenge validity of r.2 as unconstitutional and void.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners pray that an appropriate writ, direction or order be issued by this Court declaring that r. 2 aforesaid is unconstitutional and there-fore, void and inoperative.

facts.text: Section 3 of the Act defines subordinate court as all courts subordinate to High Court including Small Causes Courts under Act IX of 1880 or Act XI of 1865.

anchor.surface_text: Under s.3 of the Act a subordinate Court means all companyrts subordinate to the High Court including companyrts of Small Causes established under Act IX of 1850 or Act XI of 1865.

facts.text: Legal practitioner under the Act includes advocate, vakil, attorney, pleader, Mukhtar or revenue-agent.

anchor.surface_text: Legal practitioner means an advocate, vakil or attorney-of any High Court, a pleader, Mukhtar or revenue-agent.

facts.text: High Court under s.6 makes rules for qualifications, admission, certificates for Mukhtars of subordinate courts.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Act empowers the High Court to make from time to time rules companysistent with the Act in respect of certain matters including inter alia the qualifications, admission and certificates of proper persons to be Mukhtars of the subordinate companyrts.

facts.text: Petitioners argue s.9 gives right to practise in civil and criminal courts which cannot be curtailed by s.11 rules.

anchor.surface_text: He has submitted that s.9 of the Act gives every Mukhtar holding a certificate issued under s.7 the right to apply to be enrolled in any Civil or Criminal Court subordinate to the High Court and on enrollment in accordance with the rules-, he has the right to practise as a Mukhtar in any Civil Court and in Courts subordinate thereto and has further the right to appear, plead and act in any Criminal Court.

facts.text: Court holds impugned rule is within authority of s.11 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the impugned rule is clearly within that authority.

facts.text: No challenge to constitutional validity of s.11 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the arguments before us there was numberchallenge to the companystitutional validity of s. 11 of the Act as permitting. an unreasonable restriction of a guaranteed right

issues.text: Whether certain rules of the Patna High Court made under s.11 of the Legal Practitioners Act, 1879, particularly r.2, are invalid and void because they contravene the fundamental right of the petitioners under Art.19(1)(g) and are not saved by cl.6 thereof

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners companytend that certain rules of the Patna High Court made as far back as 1922 under s.11 of the Legal Practitioners Act, 1879  Act XVIII of 1879 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, in respect of the functions., powers and duties of Mukhtars practising in the subordinate companyrts are number invalid and void, because they companytravene the fundamental right of the petitioners guaranteed under Art. 19 1  g  of the Constitution of India and are number saved by cl.  6  thereof.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners contend that certain rules of the Patna High Court made as far back as 1922 under s.11 of the Legal Practitioners Act, 1879  Act XVIII of 1879 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, in respect of the functions., powers and duties of Mukhtars practising in the subordinate courts are not invalid and void, because they contravene the fundamental right of the petitioners guaranteed under Art. 19 1  g  of the Constitution of India and are not saved by cl.  6  thereof. The petitioners have, in particular, challenged the validity of r. 2 made by the said High Court under s. 11 of the Act and incorporated in Chapter III, Part VII of the General Rules and Circular Orders of the High Court of Judicature at Patna  Civil , 1922.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction requires linking s.9 right to practice with s.11 regulation of functions/powers/duties; rejects dissociation argument.

holdings.text: Under s.9 a distinction is made between the right of a Mukhtar to practise in civil courts (limited) and to appear, plead and act in criminal courts (unlimited); civil practice subject to s.11 rules.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.9 shows 'practise' in civil courts unlike explicit 'appear, plead, act' in criminal; anticipates s.11 delimitation.

holdings.text: In declaring functions and powers of Mukhtars under s.11, the High Court can delimit them so as to regulate the right of practice; functions/powers not dissociated from right to practise.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.11 'declaring' functions/powers/duties inherently includes delimitation/regulating practice; right depends on functions/powers.

holdings.text: s.11 expressly reserves power to make rules on functions/powers/duties, distinguishing Aswini Kumar Ghosh where no express reservation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent distinguished: unlike SC Advocates Act s.2 (no reservation), LPA s.11 expressly empowers rules delimiting practice via functions etc.

precedents.citation: Aswini Kumar Ghosh and another Arabinda Bose another 1 1953 S.C.R. 1

anchor.surface_text: Aswini Kumar Ghosh and another Arabinda Bose another 1 he has submitted that the right to practise means the right to appear and plead as well as to act on, behalf of suitors in the subordinate courts the power of the High Court to make rules under s.11 of the Act as respects the functions, powers and duties of Mukhtars practising in the subordinate courts merely means that the High Court may give effect to the right given under s. 9 by making rules, but it cannot curtail that right when therefore the High Court made the impugned rule restricting the right of Mukhtars to plead in civil courts, it did something in excess of the power given by s. 11. We are unable to accept this line of argument as correct. Sections 9 and 11 of the Act must be read together and it would be wrong to treat the right to practise given by s. 9 as dissociated from the functions, powers and duties of Mukhtars referred to in s. 11. The learned Advocate for the petitioners is reading the two sections as though one section gives an absolute right and the other section merely empowers the making of rules to effectuate that right. That, we do not think, is a proper reading of the two sections. It is worthy of note that under S. 9 itself a distinction is made between the right of a Mukhtar to practise in civil courts and his right to appear, plead and act in any criminal court. In express terms s. 9 gives every 1 1953 S.C.R. 1 Mukhtar the right to appear, plead and act in any criminal court it does not, however, give such an unlimited right in a civil court.

precedents.case_name: Aswini Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: right to practise means the right to appear and plead as well as to act on behalf of suitors and rules cannot curtail that right unless expressly authorised
precedents.cited_holding: a rule made by a High Court which denied to an Advocate of the Supreme Court the right to exercise an essential part of his function by insisting on a dual agency on the Original Side was much more than a rule of practice and constituted a serious invasion of his statutory right to practise unless the power was expressly reserved

precedents.citation: Aswini Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose 1 1933 S.C.R. 1

anchor.surface_text: Aswini Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose 1 is of any assistance to the petitioners. That decision depended on the interpretation of s. 2 of the Supreme Court Advocates Practice in High Courts Act, 1951. That section provided that notwithstanding anything contained in the Bar Councils Act or any other law regulating the conditions subject to which a person not entered in the roll of Advocates of a High Court may be permitted to practise in that High Court, every Advocate of the Supreme Court shall be entitled as of right to practise in any High Court whether or not he is an Advocate of that High Court. It was held by the majority that a rule made by a High Court which denied to an Advocate of the Supreme Court the right to exercise an essential part of his function, by insisting on a dual agency on the Original Side was much more than a rule 1 1933 S.C.R. 1 of practice and constituted a serious invasion of his statutory right to practise and the power of making such a rule, unless expressly reserved, was repugnant to the right conferred by s. 2 aforesaid

precedents.case_name: Aswini Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: unless the power was expressly reserved by the statute, a rule could not be made repugnant to the right conferred by s. 2 of the Supreme Court Advocates Practice in High Courts Act, 1951
precedents.cited_holding: a rule insisting on dual agency invaded the statutory right to practise as it was more than a rule of practice
